name: Hotel Cestelli

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I decided to stay at Hotel Cestelli for 4 nights in September after reading excellent reviews on the Lonely Planet and tripadvisor websites. Not only did it live up to all the great reviews, we felt it was the best hotel we stayed at in Italy even though we paid twice as much for others in Rome and Venice.
reviews.title: Loved this little gem!

likes.liked: — The hosts, the bed, the location

reviews.text: Our arrangements were made through the website of the hotel directly and it was easy and problem free.
reviews.title: Great little hotel at a reasonable price

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: There were so many good points to this hotel! Firstly, we were received well by the owners - Alessio and Asumi. To say they were gracious hosts is a huge understatement. We were looking for non-touristy restaurants, off-the-beaten path recommendations and good gelato. They spent a lot of time with us and every place they recommended was right on the money. Most of the restaurants recommended were filled with locals - something we wanted very much to experience.
reviews.title: Nice place, good deal.
Wonderful little corner of a wonderful city
reviews.text: Alessio and Asumi both speak English well and communicate in a thoughtful manner. They work extremely hard and are dedicated to the hotel. During our stay we had difficulty with our bank and they bent over backwards trying to help us call and sort out the problem. They also made us reservations for the Uffizi Gallery and Accademia free of charge prior to our arrival in Florence.

Our room was #3 - double bed with private bath - we paid 90 euro a night which was just about nothing given the value. The room was spacious and had a small sitting area with chairs plus a beautiful armoire to hold our clothes. The decor was very romantic - kind of vintage. The best thing about the room was the bed - it was almost a king size and hands down it was the most comfortable bed we slept on in Italy. At first we thought it was a tempurpedic mattress, but I don't think it was. At any rate, I have back problems and I slept great each night. The other winning point for me was that the place was spotless and very well kept. I also noticed that there were lots of places to hang things up as opposed to other hotel bathrooms. This may not seem like a big deal, but I don't like to put my stuff on the floor and for the first time (esp. in the shower) I didn't have to. These small things added to my comfort. I can see that bigger folks may have difficulty in the shower as it is small, but we never had a problem with the shower curtain as I read in other reviews.
reviews.title: Outstanding
Interesting stay: good and bad...
reviews.text: We had heard the usual good words about this place, and so booked there for a couple of nights. In the end, it was ok, but had some odd elements that will probably keep us from returning. I guess you get what you pay for, which isn't saying the place was bad--for the cost it's probably the best deal in this area of Firenze (Florence?). But this is to say that the place is basically a massive full-floor flat that the owners have apparently divided into an inn. That might be a valid description of many inns, but in this case it resulted in some odd effects.

reviews.title: Simply Outstanding!
reviews.text: First off, the place occupies the second floor of a tremendous five or six story apartment complex right in the heart of the old town. The building is one of many fine structures sandwiched along a cobbled road near the river that runs through town. And it's in a great location: just far enough from the huge cathedrals and Medici castle so that it's not thronged by the crowds (which never seem to dissipate--said fully aware that we constituted part of that infinite crowd during our stay). But everything in old Florence ends up being about a five or ten-minute walk away, so it's essentially near to everything. It's a fine location.

reviews.title: Thin walls and toilet queue
reviews.text: The first oddity is that when you approach the place, you must ring a buzzer to be let in--because, again, this building is a residence in which other people live. Maybe not a big deal. Once you get into the inn, on the second floor, it's striking how beautifully appointed the place is: mild and tasteful medieval decor, with low lighting, and a general atmosphere that itself is almost worth the cost of the room. You'll feel like you're in a tranquil abbey just sitting by the innkeep's desk receiving your key. As every other review here attests, the couple running the place are indeed a fantastic pair: cordial, considerate, and quick to share names of places to eat and stroll. We tried all the eateries they suggested, and they were all fantastic (and all within a ten minute walk). And more: I was trying to find a particular place which neither of them had heard of, but the fellow, un-hesitating, got out a few books and in no time had located the place I was seeking. Again, very good hosts.

Our room was massive (can't remember the number of the room). Almost too massive, if that makes sense. It was as if they'd placed a bed in a huge converted dining room; although of course I don't mean to say there was a table and settings; it was just an odd room to be sleeping in, probably not a bedroom in the flat's former incarnation. And here began the sense of being less in an inn, more a guest in someone's large and exquisite home. There was no phone in the room, no bedside clock, no television (and of course many will tsk tsk my mentioning this ommission...but frankly I like having the choice of watching the evening news or not, and don't appreciate inns that make this choice for me); and no air conditioning or fan. This last bit would be fine if you could sleep with the windows open, except that we tried doing this and the screenless windows resulted in a misquito-party buzzing around our ears through the night. The next night we kept the windows closed, and it was a bit tight with no circulation, even in a room so generous. There was a bed, a few chairs, and a wardrobe. It was elegant, and the bed was fine, but the room itself was...uncomfortable. It did, however, have a private bath, with a toilet, sink, full shower, and good supply of hot water.
reviews.title: Great place, Great hosts, Great location
Great hosts and location
reviews.text: The key situation there is strange. You receive a skeleton key to your room...but you must return the key to the innkeeper whenever you step out. And so when you return to the hotel from wherever you've gone, you must get your key back from the innkeep in order to enter your room. It strikes me as being terribly inconvenient for the innkepper to have to constantly be on alert for guests in need of their keys, or in need of handing-in their keys. Now, the innkeeps were always nearby, and so we didn't have to wait at all for the key: but it was just odd that you continually had to hand the thing in and get it back. And you only receive a key to the building's front door if you're going to be out later than 10pm: before then, you must buzz for entry. Every time. The result is that we found ourselves not returning to the hotel as often as we might have, and staying inside sometimes instead of running down to the cornerstore as we might have, simply because of this odd key situation and the akward sense it imparts of "being a bother" if you were to need a series of in-and-out jaunts. The whole thing could be remedied by simply giving guests a set of front and room door keys to retain during their stay...as does every other hotel/inn I've ever visited. This place does not. It's an odd practice, and I can only guess it has something to do with the fact the inn is a flat in a residential building.

Many reviewers have raved about the Cestelli, and we can only echo their praise. The location is fantastic (2 minutes to the Ponte Vecchio, 2 more to the Uffizi), the rooms are lovely and spacious, and spotlessly clean. But the best part is the hospitality shown by Alessio and Asumi, the charming young owners. Nothing is too much trouble for them. Before we travelled they had helped us with advice, and reserved a slot at the Uffizi for us (a must if you plan to go, because you totally avoid queueing). And then, when we got there and asked about somewhere for lunch, Alessio produced his own personal list of favourites and talked us through it, marking places up on a map, and even making reservations on our behalf. And these were out-of-the-way gems frequented by locals and tourists fortunate enough to have had advice from someone like Alessio. Like another reviewer our favourite was the Osteria Santo Spirito - a wonderful place we'd never have found by ourselves. My ravioli in a cream and lemon zest sauce was delicious, and the 'budino di panna' was to die for.
reviews.title: Wonderful hosts

reviews.text: If total tranquility is a must then the hotel is very central and therefore has traffic moving by. The rooms are double-glazed but you can hear some noise. On the other hand there is no noise from other rooms, partly perhaps because the rooms do not have tv's (hurrah). Also, if you are the kind of traveller who wants 5-star luxury, an in-house restaurant, and somewhere with spa facilities, go somewhere else. But if you value friendliness and warmth above formality, this is for you.
reviews.title: Charming hotel in location of amazing Florence

reviews.text: So thank you Alessio and Asumi, and to the rest of you - look no further!
reviews.title: Best Cheap and Charming Hotel in Florence

reviews.text: We loved Florence! My husband and I chose this hotel after reading numerous reviews and based on its location. The owners of the hotel, Alessio and Asumi, were wonderful from the moment we began our trip preparations. We booked our reservation through email and any questions we had prior to our arrival were promptly answered. Plus, the hotel rates are unbelievably reasonable for the location compared to other hotels we had researched.
reviews.title: A Perfect Place to Stay!
Great place
reviews.text: The hotel itself is located in the central tourist district and was an ideal point to start our daily excursions. Here you are only blocks away from the Uffizi, the River Arno and the Ponte Vecchio. It is located on the 2nd floor of the building, so if you have difficulty climbing stairs we wouldn't recommend staying here (especially with alot of luggage). However, the overall feeling is that you are staying in someone's home rather than in a hotel (which, in fact, you are as they have an adjacent apartment). It is so quaint and comfortable that you immediately feel welcome.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My wife and I stayed at the Hotel Cestelli for 6 nights during the last week of September, 2006. I don't have much to add to the previous reviews. Alessio and Asumi are indeed gracious hosts. We stayed in room 5, which was a large room with it's own bathroom. The street noise, in my opinion, was a bit much at times. Nothing against the Cestelli-this is probably the case in pretty much any room in the city that faces a street. Ear plugs should do the trick. Regarding the previous comments about having to be buzzed into the hotel, we found this to be no problem at all. We were always buzzed in promptly and met by Alessio and/or Asumi with our room key and a warm greeting. In short, the Cestelli is a nice hotel choice, and we would gladly stay there again if we return to Florence.
reviews.title: Cestelli is a Unique Hotel

likes.liked: — Alessio and Asumi, as well as the great location

reviews.title: Loved Hotel Cestelli
reviews.text: We stayed at Hotel Cestelli for 4 nights and really loved it. The location is terrific, the owners are fantastic and friendly, and the room had a wonderful antique look and feel to it. Highly recommended.

Staying in the Hotel Cestelli is a unique esperience, taking the traveler back in time to a previous era when one stayed in small family style hotels and felt like a person and not a number. This is not an experience for a person who is expecting four star service for two star prices. There is no TV, phone, or other entertainment in your room. Some rooms have baths, others share a spotless large bathroom that is cleaned constantly. Yes, you do hear those motorcycles, but you hear them everywhere in this dynamic town. It quiets down after 11 PM. The owners are personable but not intrusive, and one of them is always there. You hand in your key to one of them when you go out, and they let you in by the buzzer outside and hand you your key when you enter. They live right there in a private area, so you are in a way a guest in their home. This was fine for me as a 72 year old single male, who likes the feeling that if I didn't return someone would come looking for me! The single room was spare, in an old Italian antique fashion, with huge ceiling and sink and bidet. It was abit dark, but one is rarely there except to sleep. It had a unique atmosphere. I enjoyed a number of meals at the excellent restaurant they recommmended nearby at really good prices. I loved the street it was on...very stylish and nice shops and friendly people. The owner got up at 6:15 am to help me into a waiting taxi for the train. All in, I would not hesitate to go back, and probably would pay abit more for a private bath. The personal experience is worth experiencing for travelers looking for more than just impersonal service and predictable rooms. In sum, a rare find.
reviews.title: A Magical Step Back in TIme....
Beautiful contemporary "old fashioned" small hotel
reviews.text: There are already a lot a reviews, so I'll keep it brief. The owners are very nice and friendly, very helpful, youthful, and both enthusiastic and discreet. (Perfect!)

reviews.title: Great Hotel
reviews.text: The hotel is "old fashioned" in that it is like small European hotels from days past -- a big old building where you need to get buzzed in and go up some stairs. Everything on a small and personal scale (the owners seem to always be there -- or at least one of them), and you drop off your key when you leave. If you're going to be out late, they'll give you a key to the exterior doors.

description: Situated in a 12th century palace off Via de' Tornabuoni and just steps away from Ponte Vecchio. Minimalistic and calm atmosphere inside enhanced by subdued lighting and Japanese simplicity. Renaissance meets Zen.
